definition: to open (a door)/to open up (for development)/to dispel/to refute/to repudiate

sentences.english: It is nearly impossible to disprove a rumor.
sentences.chinese: 要闢謠幾乎是不可能的。

sentences.english: A rush of salt in the multilateral tide, under the rumours, gradually died down.
sentences.chinese: 一場食鹽的搶購潮，在多方闢謠之下，逐漸平息。

sentences.english: First, let's dispel some common myths about raw milk.
sentences.chinese: 首先，讓我們爲生奶一些常見的誤解闢謠。

sentences.english: She has dismissed the rumours of her resignation as pure speculation.
sentences.chinese: 他闢謠說，有關她辭職的傳聞純屬猜測的事。

sentences.english: Yu denied all the death rumors via micro-blog shortly after they buzzed online.
sentences.chinese: 餘秋雨經過其微博第一時間發佈闢謠聲明。

definition: frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
to crack down on/to take severe measures against
to allow in fresh air/to allow a prisoner out for exercise/to give out information
to give orders/to spread news or rumors/to leak certain information intentionally
to have one's spirits dampened/to feel disappointed
to drive a vehicle for its owner (often as a paid service for sb who has consumed alcohol) (abbr. for 代理駕駛|代理驾驶[dai4 li3 jia4 shi3])/substitute driver (abbr. for 代駕司機|代驾司机[dai4 jia4 si1 ji1])
righteous indignation fills one's breast (idiom); to feel indignant at injustice
to criticize (as a matter of principle)
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
